snippet: Two months after the ouster of President Mohamed Morsi, the Egyptian government is struggling to control the Islamist strongholds in rural southern regions of the country.
abstract: Convoy of more than a dozen armored police and army vehicles arrive in Dalga, Egypt, south of the capital of Cairo, as part of an expedition to capture a single fugitive Islamist; scale of operation is the latest indication of the challenge the military-led government appears to face as it struggles to control the Islamist strongholds in the rural southern regions of the country.

byline.contributor: Amro Hassan contributed reporting from Minya, Egypt, and Dalga, Egypt.

lead_paragraph: Two months after the ouster of President Mohamed Morsi, the Egyptian government is struggling to control the Islamist strongholds in rural southern regions of the country.

headline.main: In Islamist Bastions of Egypt, the Army Treads Carefully, and Christians Do, Too
headline.print_headline: In Islamist Bastions of Egypt, the Army Treads Carefully, and Christians Do, Too

keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
